intro: Rancagua glaberrima, commonly known as the Chilean thistle, is a flowering plant native to the central and southern regions of Chile. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to the temperate climate of its native habitat. Its leaves are usually spiny and covered in a dense layer of fine hairs, while its flowers are yellow and occur in clusters. Rancagua glaberrima is often found in open areas such as fields and along coastal regions.
